main.name: Nicholas Lewis
main.description: Recent Computer Science graduate from California State University, Sacramento with a passion for hackathons, game development, and creative tech projects
main.bio: Hi, my name is Nick. I recently graduated with a Bachelor's Degree in Computer Science from Sacramento State University. I'm passionate about building creative tech solutions, especially through hackathons and hands-on projects with Raspberry Pi. I also bring a strong work ethic from my experience as a Starbucks Barista at Target.
main.contactmessage: Get in touch with me to learn more

education.degree: A.S in Computer Science For Transfer

education.description: Completed courses in Parallel Programming with GPUs, Computer Game Architecture, and a year-long Senior Project. Participated in Sac State's Spring 2025 AI Hackathon, building an AI-powered mental health chatbot.

work.title: StarBucks Barista
work.description: Preparing and serving a variety of coffee and other beverages, providing excellent customer service, and maintaining a clean and organized work environment.

projects.title: Reimagining the Sac State LIFE Mobile Application
projects.category: Led development of a student-centered mobile app featuring a personalized dashboard, wellness bar, and AI-powered chatbot for support and engagement.

projects.title: Big Boom
projects.category: Big Boom is a fast-paced multiplayer tank game with real-time physics and power-ups, built in Java using the TAGE engine.

projects.title: Dynamic-PDF-Generation
projects.category: PDF Generation, storage, and Email delivery with Google Firebase. Uses JavaScript and LaTeX.

projects.title: Custom Command Line Argument Processor (myxargs)
projects.category: Designed a C-based command-line utility inspired by Unix ‘xargs‘

testimonials.text: It's not at all important to get it right the first time. It's vitally important to get it right the last time.
Computer Science is no more computers than astronomy is about telescopes.
Programs must be written for people to read, and only incidentally for machines to execute.
